title-group.article-title: Joint association and interaction of birth weight and lifestyle with hypertension: A cohort study in UK Biobank

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: Low birth weight and unhealthy lifestyle are both associated with an increased risk of hypertension. The authors aimed to assess the joint association and interaction of birth weight and lifestyle with incident hypertension. The authors included 205 522 participants free of hypertension at baseline from UK Biobank. A healthy lifestyle score was constructed using information on body mass index, physical activity, diet, smoking status and alcohol intake. Cox proportional hazard models were used to investigate the impact of birth weight, healthy lifestyle score and their joint effect on hypertension. The authors documented 13 548 (6.59%) incident hypertension cases during a median of 8.6 years of follow‐up. The multivariate adjusted hazard ratios and 95% confidence intervals were 1.12 (1.09, 1.15) per kg lower birth weight and 0.76 (0.75, 0.77) per score increment in healthy lifestyle score. Healthy lifestyle reduced the risk of hypertension in any category of different birth weight groups. The preventive effect of healthy lifestyle on hypertension was the most pronounced at lower birth weight with <2500 g and 2500–2999 g, respectively. Addictive interaction between birth weight and healthy lifestyle score was observed with the relative excess risk due to interaction of 0.04 (0.03, 0.05). Our findings emphasized the importance of healthy lifestyle for hypertension prevention, especially among the high‐risk population with lower birth weight.

institution-wrap.institution: National Natural Science Foundation of China

award-group.funding-source: National Clinical Research Center for Obstetrics and Gynecology

p.mixed-citation: ZhangZ, LiuX, HuangN, et al. Joint association and interaction of birth weight and lifestyle with hypertension: A cohort study in UK Biobank. J Clin Hypertens. 2024;26:483–490. 10.1111/jch.14792PMC1108842638491763

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Hypertension has been one of the most common chronic noncommunicable diseases. Despite widespread efforts to prevent and treat hypertension, the number of cases worldwide has doubled in the last three decades. 1 It reached over 1 billion globally in 2019, of which the prevalence was 32% in women and 34% in men among adults. 2 Hypertension not only causes great suffering to patients, but also places a huge burden on the healthcare system. 3 An estimated 8.5 million deaths per year are attributed to higher systolic blood pressure. 1 It showed that the United States spends $109.1 billion annually on residents with hypertension. The direct cost of hypertension to the U.S. population will even increase to $200 billion by 2030. 4 High blood pressure is one of the most important risk factors for ischemic heart disease, stroke, and chronic kidney disease. 1 , 5 , 6 Early life development has also been shown to have an impact on the risk of hypertension in adulthood. 7 Low birth weight, a widely used indicator of growth retardation, has been shown in recent studies to increase the risk of adult hypertension. 8

Moreover, existing studies have shown that a healthy lifestyle can reduce the risk of hypertension, including healthy diet and exercise habits, and the abstinence of smoking and alcohol, etc. 9 Nowadays, multiple lifestyle factors in most researches have been usually integrated as the Healthy Lifestyle Score. 10 , 11 However, few studies have examined the potential interactions between early‐life health status and lifestyle factors on the risk of hypertension. Therefore, we aimed to prospectively assess the joint effects and potential interactions of birth weight and the healthy lifestyle score, which comprehensively incorporated body mass index (BMI), physical activity, diet, smoking status, and alcohol intake, on incident hypertension risk among 205 522 participants from UK Biobank in the present study.

sec.title: Study population
sec.p: UK Biobank is a very large, population‐based prospective study with over 500 000 participants aged 40−69 years when recruited in 2006−2010. Extensive health‐related information was collected through a self‐completed touch‐screen questionnaire, physical and functional measures, and collection of biological samples. It is designed to combine broad and precise exposure assessment with comprehensive follow‐up and characterization of many different health‐related outcomes. 12 After excluding participants with missing birth weight information (N = 222 261), those with hypertension at baseline (N = 69 394) and those with missing information on healthy lifestyle scores (N = 5350), a total of 205 522 participants were left for analysis.

sec.title: Assessment of birth weight, healthy lifestyle score, and hypertension
sec.p: Birth weight was collected at baseline using a questionnaire either in kilograms directly, or in imperial pounds and ounces. We categorized birth weight as <2500 g, 2500–2999 g, 3000–3499 g, 3500–3999 g, and ≥4000 g. 13 Incident hypertension was diagnosed based on ICD‐10 code I00‐I99 in the in‐patient hospital register. 14 , 15 Date and diagnosis for hospital admissions were obtained through records linkage to the Hospital Episode Statistics for England, Scottish Morbidity Record data for Scotland, and the Patients Episode Database for Wales.

The healthy lifestyle score is a composite of multiple common lifestyle indicators. Healthy lifestyle score includes five lifestyle factors: body mass index (BMI), physical activity, diet, smoking status, and alcohol intake. 16 BMI < 25 kg/m2 was defined as healthy; ≥150 min of moderate activity per week or ≥75 min of vigorous or mixed activity per week was defined as healthy; a healthy diet was defined as including four or more of vegetables, fruits, fish, processed and nonprocessed meats; never smoking was defined as healthy; and alcohol intake ≤14 g/day was defined as healthy. Each factor is calculated as 1 score, with higher scores indicating healthier lifestyles.

sec.title: Assessment of the covariates
sec.p: Self‐reported information on age at recruitment, sex, ethnicity, education, and employment was obtained through the questionnaire. Weight and height were measured during the baseline assessment center visit and body mass index (BMI) was calculated as weight (kg) divided by height (meters) squared.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: We compared the participants’ basic characteristics in the different hypertension groups using Student's t‐test for quantitative variables and the chi‐square test for categorical variables. Cox proportional hazard models were applied to estimate hazard ratios (HRs) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) for the associations of birth weight categories and healthy lifestyle score with the occurrence of hypertension. Follow‐up time was calculated from the recruitment date to the first diagnosis of hypertension, lost to follow‐up, death, or end of the current follow‐up, whichever came first. The adjusted multivariable models were adjusted for age, sex, ethnic, education, and employment. To examine the dose‐response relationship, we quantified linear trends across birth weight and healthy lifestyle score categories by assigning median values to each category and modelling them as continuous variables. We accessed the potential nonlinear association of birth weight and hypertension through a likelihood ratio test comparing the model with only a linear term of birth weight against the model with linear plus cubic spline term. 17 , 18

To examine the joint effects, participants were classified by birth weight and healthy lifestyle score to estimate hypertension risks with Cox regression model adjusting for the same set of covariates. To estimate the additive interaction, we calculate the relative excess risk due to interaction (RERI) 19 and attributable proportion (AP). 20 We generated a binary categorical variable combining birth weight and healthy lifestyle score, and calculate the population attributable risk (PAR) to estimate the theoretical proportion of incident hypertension that would have been prevented if all participants had birth weight ≥3500 g and high healthy lifestyle score. 21 Statistical analyses were performed with STATA/SE version 16.0. Statistical significance was set at two‐sided p < .05.

sec.title: Population characteristics
sec.p: The mean (standard deviation) age of our study population was 54.1 (8.05) years old, of which 63.05% were female. We documented a total of 13 548 (6.59%) incident hypertension cases during a median of 8.6 years of follow‐up. The population baseline characteristics were listed in Table 1. Compared with those who did not have hypertension, those who did were older, had a higher proportion of males, were more likely to be white British, had a higher body mass index, and lower birth weight. In addition, they were less likely to be highly educated and in paid employment. Participants with hypertension were more likely to have lower healthy lifestyle score compared to those without hypertension (p < .001).

caption.p: Baseline characteristics of participants in the UK Biobank study according to hypertension (N = 205 522).

fn.p: Abbreviations: BMI, body mass index; SD, standard deviation.

sec.title: Associations between birth weight and healthy lifestyle score with hypertension
sec.p: Table 2 showed the associations between different birth weight categories and healthy lifestyle scores with hypertension. Low birth weight was associated with an increased risk of hypertension. The multivariate adjusted hazard ratios (aHRs) and 95% confidence intervals (95% CIs) for hypertension in those with lower birth weights (<2500 g, 2500–2999 g, and 3000–3499 g) compared to those in the middle birth weight category (3500–3999 g) were 1.30 (1.22, 1.38), 1.17 (1.11, 1.24), and 1.06 (1.01, 1.11), respectively. The association between high birth weight (≥4000 g) and risk of hypertension was not significant in the multivariable adjusted model (aHR 1.01, 95%CI 0.96, 1.07). The aHR (95% CI) of hypertension per kg decrease of birth weight was 1.12 (1.09, 1.15). The tests for linear trend and nonlinear trend were both significant (p < .001).

caption.p: Risk for incident hypertension according to birth weight and healthy lifestyle score groups in UK Biobank.

fn.p: Abbreviations: CI, confidence interval; HLS, healthy lifestyle score; HR, hazard ratio; PAR, population attributable risk.
Adjusted for age, sex, ethnic, education, employment.
Nonlinear trend was tested using likelihood ratio method comparing model with linear trend only with model with both linear plus cubic spline terms.
Linear trend across birth weight categories was quantified by assigning median value to each category and modeling this variable as continuous variable.

sec.p: The aHRs (95% CIs) for hypertension in the low‐mediate risk healthy lifestyle score (2–3) and the low risk healthy lifestyle score (4–5) were 0.65 (0.63, 0.68) and 0.39 (0.36, 0.41) compared to the high risk healthy lifestyle score (0–1). The healthier lifestyle score was also associated with a decreased risk of hypertension in a dose–response manner (p for linear trend < .001).

In stratified analysis, we classified the participants according to the different categories of birth weight and healthy lifestyle score. The higher healthy lifestyle scores significantly reduced the risk of hypertension in each birth weight category (Table 3). The lowest risk of developing hypertension was observed in the subgroup with the lowest birth weight (<2500 g) and the highest healthy lifestyle score (aHR 0.32, 95% CI 0.26, 0.39). It was estimated that 53.6% of hypertension incident would be prevented theoretically if the total population had birth weight <2500 g and the highest healthy lifestyle score. The PAR% of hypertension was decreased to 44.9%, 43.5%, 40.6%, and 47.0% among the participants with birth weight 2500–2999 g, 3000–3499 g, 3500–3999 g, ≥4000 g, respectively.

caption.p: Stratified analysis on incident hypertension risk by birth weight and healthy lifestyle score in UK Biobank.

fn.p: Abbreviations: CI, confidence interval; HLS, healthy lifestyle score; HR, hazard ratio; PAR, population attributable risk.
Adjusted for age, sex, ethnic, education, employment.

sec.title: Joint association and interaction of birth weight and healthy lifestyle score with hypertension
sec.p: In joint analyses, we classified the participants according to the joint categories of birth weight and healthy lifestyle score. The risk of hypertension increased with lower birth weight in all three healthy lifestyle score categories (Figure 1). The strength of the association between lower birth weight and risk of hypertension increased in the high risk healthy lifestyle score and the low‐mediate risk healthy lifestyle score. The low risk healthy lifestyle score can reduce the effect of lower birth weight on the risk of developing hypertension. The highest risk of developing hypertension was observed in the subgroup with the lowest birth weight (<2500 g) and the high risk healthy lifestyle score (aHR 3.23, 95% CI 2.77, 3.78).

caption.p: The joint association of categories of healthy lifestyle score and birth weight with the risk of incident hypertension. Hazard Ratios (95% CIs) were estimated with Cox proportional hazard models adjusted for age, sex, ethnic, education, employment. CI, confidence interval; HLS, healthy lifestyle score.

sec.p: As shown in Table 4, we detected a significant additive interaction between birth weight and healthy lifestyle score on hypertension risk with relative excess risk due to interaction of 0.04 (95% CI 0.03, 0.05, p < .001) after multivariate adjustment. The attributable proportions of joint effect were 17.4% (95% CI −6.3%, 41.1%) for birth weight alone, 72.4% (95% CI 52.3%, 92.4%) for healthy lifestyle score alone, and 10.3% (95% CI 5.6%, 14.9%) for their interaction. We performed a sensitivity analysis about accounting for additional confounders including TDI and other early life exposures (maternal smoking and breastfeeding status). The results were unchanged (data not shown).

caption.p: Attributing effects to additive interaction between birth weight and healthy lifestyle score on risk of hypertension.

tr.td: Relative excess risk due to interaction
Attributable proportion for birth weight b
Attributable proportion for healthy lifestyle score

fn.p: Adjusted for age, sex, ethnic, education, employment.
Birth weight was divided into three groups (low risk group: 3500−3999 g; mediate risk group: (2500–3500 g and ≥4000 g); high risk group: < 2500 g).

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: In this prospective cohort study, we found that low birth weight and unhealthy lifestyles were jointly associated with an increased risk of incident hypertension. The highest risk of developing hypertension was observed in the lowest birth weight (<2500 g) and the high risk healthy lifestyle score (aHR 3.23, 95% CI 2.77, 3.78). Hypertension risk with the combined effect from low birth weight and low healthy lifestyle score exceeded the sum of the individual effects of the two exposures (RERI = 0.04, 95% CI 0.03, 0.05). More public measures should be taken to reduce the incidence of hypertension due to birth weight and unhealthy lifestyles, especially among those with low birth weight and concomitant higher risk of healthy lifestyles.

Low birth weight has been a recognized risk factor for hypertension. 8 , 22 In a Mendelian randomization study, no association was observed between genetically determined birth weight and risk of hypertension or increased blood pressure levels in adulthood. 23 In a systematic review and meta‐analysis of 31 studies, the prevalence of hypertension was found to be higher in individuals with high birth weight. 24 In another meta‐analysis, however, high birth weight was found to be negatively associated with the occurrence of hypertension. 25 In the present study, low birth weight increased the risk of adulthood hypertension. The association between high birth weight and hypertension was attenuated after multivariate adjustment, and higher birth weight did not increase the risk of hypertension, which is consistent with previous findings. 26 Nowadays, healthy lifestyle scores was combined with multiple lifestyle factors on health status and are being widely used. 27 , 28 , 29 Our findings found a relatively stronger association between lower risk healthy lifestyle score and risk of hypertension. A previous study applied similar estimation to assess the single effect of BMI, sedentary behavior, meat and fish and vegetable and fruit intake, alcohol consumption, smoking, and urinary sodium excretion on the risk of developing hypertension, and the consistent results were observed. 30 Those results suggest that a combination of healthy lifestyles factors may reduce the risk of hypertension.

However, few studies have examined the potential interaction of birth weight and lifestyle factors on the effect of hypertension. We found that the intensity of the association between low birth weight and risk of hypertension increased in the high‐risk healthy lifestyle score. Many epidemiologists have argued that the biological interaction should be assessed on an additive scale. 31 We detected an additive interaction between birth weight and healthy lifestyle score on hypertension risk with relative excess risk due to interaction of 0.04 (95% CI 0.03, 0.05). Our results implied that the combined effect was 0.04 times higher than the sum of the individual effects. Those support the notion that low birth weight may be incorporated into high‐risk healthy lifestyle score estimation for adulthood hypertension and public efforts to promote healthy lifestyle status will lead to an overall reduction in hypertension risk among adults.

Little is known about the biological mechanisms underlying the association between low birth weight and the risk of hypertension. It may be primarily associated with impaired vascular structure and abnormal expression of proteins related to inflammation and ion channels. 32 Alterations in microvascular and macrovascular structure observed in low birth weight patients affect vascular system function and endothelial dysfunction could be observed in those individuals, which played an important role in the pathogenesis of hypertension. 33 Lifestyle behaviors may have an effect on blood pressure by modulating vascular endothelial function and the renin‐angiotensin‐aldosterone system. 9 It may also be associated with hypertension through a range of metabolic and molecular alterations that include suppression of insulin resistance, inflammation, and oxidative stress to reduce the risk of developing hypertension. 34 , 35 , 36 Our additive interaction analysis confirms that a healthy lifestyle antagonizes the effect of low birth weight on the increased risk of developing hypertension. This may be related to the fact that a healthy lifestyle modulates vascular endothelial function and reduces inflammatory factors, thereby reducing the risk of hypertension in low birth weight patients. This needs to be confirmed by more in‐depth studies.

The strengths of this study are the large study population, long‐term follow‐up, and the prospective study design of the UK Biobank. Secondly, we comprehensively assessed detailed information on lifestyle and other health‐related factors to establish a healthy lifestyle score. Thirdly, this study is the first to examine the interaction of birth weight and lifestyle with hypertension through a large follow‐up sample, which has important public health values. Our study also has several limitations. Information on birth weight was determined by participants' self‐reported information, which led to information bias. Furthermore, although the test for linear trend was significant, we could not exclude an overall nonlinear relationship between birth weight and hypertension (p < .001 for nonlinear trend). Preterm birth is associated with increased cardiometabolic risk and risk of developing hypertension. Due to the lack of information on the variable of preterm birth, premature infants were not excluded from this study, which may affect the strength of the results. Further studies are needed to validate the conclusions.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: Our study found that both low birth weight and a high‐risk healthy lifestyle could increase the risk of incident hypertension, and the combination of low level of birth weight and high‐risk healthy lifestyle factors further elevated the hypertension risk. The findings provide new evidence that prenatal and lifestyle factors may jointly influence the risk of adulthood hypertension. Relevant measures in improving low birth weight and lifestyle may be a powerful strategy for preventing hypertension.

sec.title: AUTHOR CONTRIBUTIONS
sec.p: Tao Huang and Nan Li conceived and designed the paper, and critically revised the manuscript. Ming Jin analyzed the data. Ziyi Zhang drafted the manuscript and made subsequent revisions. Xiaowen Liu, Ninghao Huang, Zhenhuang Zhuang, Zeping Yang, and Xiaojing Liu contribute to key interpretations of important intellectual content. All authors approved the final manuscript as submitted and agree to be accountable for all aspects of the work.

sec.title: CONFLICT OF INTEREST STATEMENT
sec.p: The authors declare that they have no known competing interests in this paper.

ack.title: ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
ack.p: This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (grant number 81903327), Beijing Natural Science Foundation (grant number 7234401, 7222245), Postdoctoral Science Foundation of China (grant number 88014Y0226), National Clinical Research Center for Obstetrics and Gynecology (Peking University Third Hospital) (grant number BYSYSZKF2021001), the startup funding from the “Incubation” Program of China and Peking University Health Science Center (grant number BMU2017YB003), and Young Elite Scientist Sponsorship Program by CAST (YESS) (grant number 2018QNRC001). The most important acknowledgment is to the participants in the study and the members of the survey teams.

sec.title: DATA AVAILABILITY STATEMENT
sec.p: All data analyzed in this paper are available from the corresponding author upon reasonable request.
